wikitext.*:
"'''Tree-men'''" was a term used by [[Samwise Gamgee]] in [[The Shire]] for some unspecified creatures.<ref name="hobbit">{{FR|I2}}, pp. 58-9</ref>

== History ==
On [[12 April]] in the year [[Third Age 3018|3018]] of the late [[Third Age]], Samwise Gamgee told [[Ted Sandyman]] in the [[Green Dragon]] about rumours regarding sightings of giant Tree-men beyond the [[North Moors]]. When Ted questioned Sam's credibility, Sam stated that his cousin [[Halfast Gamgee]] actually saw one of these [[giants]] which apparently "was as big as an elm tree, and walking - walking seven yards to a stride". Ted still questioned the credibility of the rumour.<ref name="hobbit"/>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In "[[The Tale of E채rendel]]" in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales Part Two]]'', [[E채rendil]] set sail in [[Vingilot]] and had many voyages in his quest to reach [[Valinor]]. During one of these voyages, Vingilot was driven south by the wind into [[Far Harad|dark regions]] and fire-mountains where he encountered "Tree-men" alongside [[Haradrim|Sun-dwellers]], [[Pygmies]], and ''[[Sarqindi]]''.<ref name="south">{{LT2|V}}, pp. 254, 261</ref>

In the first iteration of the conversation at the Green Dragon, Samwise never names the creature, and only used the word "giants", describing them as being "as big as a tower or leastways a tree".<ref name="first">{{RS|2XV}}, pp. 254</ref> Tolkien changed this phrase soon afterwards, adding the term "'''Tree-Men'''" and briefly dropping "or leastways a tree" from the sentence.<ref name="first"/> In the second draft of the conversation, Tolkien revised the spelling to '''Tree-men''',<ref name="second">{{RS|3XIX2}}, pp. 319</ref> yet in a later draft, Tolkien spelled the term as '''Treemen'''.<ref name="last">{{RS|3XXII}}, pp. 386</ref> Sometime later, Tolkien changed the term back to Tree-men and the comparison from a tower to an elm tree.

On [[28 February]] in [[1964]], Tolkien stated in a letter to James Heaf that he did "not think it was an [[Entwives|Entwife]] which Hal saw on the North Moors" and suggested that the Tree-man may have been "a [[Trolls|troll]]" of some kind.<ref name="unpublished">[https://www.tolkienguide.com/guide/letters/544?q=tag%3AEntwives TCG Letter #544] on the Tolkien Collector Guide</ref> While trolls were never said to be capable of "walking seven yards to a stride"<ref name="hobbit"/>, it is possible that some details of the sighting may have been exaggerated by Halfast.

== Portrayal in adaptations ==
=== ''The Lord of the Rings Online'' ===
In the video game ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'', there are many different types of trolls, one of these groups are '''Wood-trolls'''. These Wood-trolls are often mistaken for [[Ents]] and Giants. There is also a quest in the Shire wherein a Hobbit requests that the player investigate sightings of a walking tree in the North Moors. The '''Walking Tree''' in question turns out to be a [[Huorns|Huorn]] that is trapped by [[Spiders]].

===''The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power''===
In the [[The Great Wave|fourth episode]] of the first season of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]]'', [[Galadriel]] tells [[Elendil]] of the stone-giants of the [[North Moors]].<ref>''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]]'', Season One, 4. "[[The Great Wave]]"</ref> While the term "Tree-men" is not mentioned, it can be inferred that Galadriel is referring to the Tree-men rather than the giants of the [[Misty Mountains]] since in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', the Tree-men are described as possibly being akin to giants,<ref name="hobbit"/> and that giants were never said to dwell in the North Moors.
